content:
ParallelTimeline Class

Definition

Defines a segment of time that may contain child Timeline objects. These child timelines become active according to their respective stem.Windows.Media.Animation.Timeline.BeginTime* properties. Also, child timelines are able to overlap (run in parallel) with each other.

In this Article

public class ParallelTimeline : System.Windows.Media.Animation.TimelineGroup

Remarks

ParallelTimeline objects can be children (nested inside) of a Storyboard. This can provide better encapsulation of timing sequences in complex animations.

ParallelTimeline has its own BeginTime property therefore all child timeline BeginTime values are relative to the parent ParallelTimeline value for BeginTime.

Fields

SlipBehaviorProperty

Identifies the stem.Windows.Media.Animation.ParallelTimeline.SlipBehavior* dependency property.

public static readonly System.Windows.DependencyProperty SlipBehaviorProperty;

Remarks

The identifier for the SlipBehavior dependency property.

Properties

SlipBehavior

Gets or sets a value that specifies how this timeline will behave when one or more of its Timeline children slips.

public System.Windows.Media.Animation.SlipBehavior SlipBehavior { get; set; }
Value
SlipBehavior

A value that indicates how this timeline will behave when one or more of its Timeline children slips. The default value is SlipBehavior.

Remarks

It is often desirable to synchronize animations and media. However, this is complicated by the fact that media playback can be delayed by loading or buffering making it difficult to reliably play an animation along with media. The SlipBehavior property is used to determine what happens when media and animations are played together. A value of SlipBehavior (default) specifies that animation timelines do not need to be synced and will play when specified regardless of the state of other media in the timeline. A value of SlipBehavior on the other hand, specifies that an animation will wait (slip) until media is ready to play. The diagrams below illustrate this behavior.

This Storyboard plays a video and an animation. When SlipBehavior is set to SlipBehavior and the Duration property of the Storyboard is set to Automatic, the Storyboard grows to play all media and animations.

This Storyboard has a SlipBehavior of SlipBehavior and a Duration of 5 seconds which gives media and animations 5 seconds to play regardless of how much they slip.

This Storyboard has a SlipBehavior of SlipBehavior. Note that the DoubleAnimation (and any other non-media children of the Storyboard) does not progress unless the media timeline is also progressing. If the media takes a while to load, or if it is buffering, the animation will wait (slips) with it. This allows animations to synchronize with a single media file.

This Storyboard has a SlipBehavior of SlipBehavior and a Duration of 5 seconds. In this scenario, the media file and animation are guaranteed to play for 5 seconds.

Metadata properties set to true None

Methods

Clone()

Creates a modifiable clone of this ParallelTimeline, making deep copies of this object's values. When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.

public System.Windows.Media.Animation.ParallelTimeline Clone ();
Returns
ParallelTimeline

A modifiable clone of the current object. The cloned object's stem.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen* property will be false even if the source's stem.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen* property was true.

Remarks

This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen Freezable objects (or any Freezable object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.

For more information, see Clone.

CloneCurrentValue()

Creates a modifiable clone of this ParallelTimeline object, making deep copies of this object's current values. Resource references, data bindings, and animations are not copied, but their current values are.

public System.Windows.Media.Animation.ParallelTimeline CloneCurrentValue ();
Returns
ParallelTimeline

A modifiable clone of the current object. The cloned object's stem.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen* property will be false even if the source's stem.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen* property was true.

Remarks

This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen Freezable objects (or any Freezable object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.

For more information, see CloneCurrentValue.

CreateInstanceCore()

Creates a new instance of this Freezable.

protected override System.Windows.Freezable CreateInstanceCore ();
Returns
Freezable

The new Freezable.

Remarks

This method overrides the CreateInstanceCore method.

GetNaturalDurationCore(Clock)

Return the natural duration (duration of a single iteration) from a specified Clock.

protected override System.Windows.Duration GetNaturalDurationCore (System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock clock);
clock
Clock

The Clock to return the natural duration from.

Returns
Duration

The Duration quantity representing the natural duration.

Remarks

A natural duration is the period of a single iteration. If this method returns Automatic it means that the natural duration is unknown. In this case, the NaturalDuration of the Clock is determined by the author. For example, the duration of streaming media would be determined by the provider of the streaming media.
